children.name: Vertex cover
A vertex cover for a graph is a set of vertices which is incident with every edge.
keywords: A vertex cover for a graph is a set of vertices which is incident with every edge.

children.name: The following problem is NP-complete: Input. A graph and a number k. Question. Is there a vertex cover of size ≤ k?
keywords: The following problem is NP-complete: Input. A graph and a number k. Question. Is there a vertex cover of size ≤ k?

children.name: Recursive procedure
keywords: Recursive procedure

children.name: If k vertices are “yes” then stop.
keywords: If k vertices are “yes” then stop.

children.name: Take the first undecided vertex v .
keywords: Take the first undecided vertex v .

children.name: If all neighbours of v are decided, make v “yes” if it has some “no” neighbour, and “no” otherwise. Try the next v.
keywords: If all neighbours of v are decided, make v “yes” if it has some “no” neighbour, and “no” otherwise. Try the next v.

children.name: If all neighbours of v are decided, make v “yes” if it has some “no” neighbour, and “no” otherwise. Try the next v.
keywords: If all neighbours of v are decided, make v “yes” if it has some “no” neighbour, and “no” otherwise. Try the next v.

children.name: Succeed if one of the following succeds:
keywords: Succeed if one of the following succeds:

children.name: 1. set v to “yes”, and recurse
keywords: 1. set v to “yes”, and recurse

children.name: 2. set v to “no”, set all of its undecided neighbours to “yes”, and recurse
keywords: 2. set v to “no”, set all of its undecided neighbours to “yes”, and recurse

children.name: The recursion tree is a binary tree of depth at most k
keywords: The recursion tree is a binary tree of depth at most k

children.name: Treewidth
A graph with ports is a graph with distinguished distinguished vertices.

children.name: ports
keywords: ports

children.name: Definition. A graph has treewidth k ∈ {1,2, ...} if it can be constructed using the following operations, so that in every moment at most k+1 ports are used.
keywords: Definition. A graph has treewidth k ∈ {1,2, ...} if it can be constructed using the following operations, so that in every moment at most k+1 ports are used.

Problem 1. Given a graph, does it contain a clique of size k?

keywords: Problem 2. Given k nondeterministic automata, is there some word accepted by all of them?

children.name: Lemma: If Problem 2 is FPT, then so is Problem 1.
keywords: Lemma: If Problem 2 is FPT, then so is Problem 1.

children.name: From k-clique to automata
Given a graph, we want to know if it contains a clique of size k.
keywords: Given a graph, we want to know if it contains a clique of size k.

children.name: We will define a Turing machine of size O(vertices3) such that:

children.name: The graph has a clique of size k

keywords: iff

children.name: The Turing machine has an accepting computation of length ≤ k3
keywords: The Turing machine has an accepting computation of length ≤ k3

children.name: We define k automata over the alphabet of vertices as follows.
keywords: We define k automata over the alphabet of vertices as follows.

children.name: for every i < j ∈ {1,.., k}, the i-th and j-th letters in the input word describe an edge in the graph
keywords: for every i < j ∈ {1,.., k}, the i-th and j-th letters in the input word describe an edge in the graph

children.name: From Turing to clique 2
1. the window is consistent with the transition relation of the Turing machine
keywords: 1. the window is consistent with the transition relation of the Turing machine

children.name: 2. if the window covers top-left corner, then the initial state is used there
keywords: 2. if the window covers top-left corner, then the initial state is used there

children.name: 3. if the window covers a state in the last line, then that state is accepting
keywords: 3. if the window covers a state in the last line, then that state is accepting

children.name: Graph of windows: vertices are windows, and an edge connects two windows if they are consistent (agree on the overlap).
